metadata.titleEn: Manual observation of meteorological data in Hulugou sub-basin of Heihe River Basin (2011)
metadata.description:
1. Data overview            
In 2011, the manual observation data set of standard meteorological field of Qilian station was used to observe various meteorological elements at 8:00, 14:00 and 20:00 every day.            
2. Data content            
Data content includes dry bulb temperature, wet bulb temperature, maximum temperature, minimum temperature, surface temperature (0cm), shallow surface temperature (5cm, 10cm, 15cm, 20cm), maximum ground temperature and minimum ground temperature.            
3. Time and space            
Geographic coordinates: longitude: 99.9e; latitude: 38.3n; altitude: 2980m

background: Understanding cryospheric hydrology and the effects of cryospheric changes on river runoff is critical for sustainable water management especially in arid inland river basins such as those in northwest China where water resources mainly come from alpine areas. The Earthâ€™s cryosphere is facing rapid changes in the duration, extent, and mass of snow and ice, which have had multiple impacts on the environment across a range of temporal and spatial scales. Changes in mountain snow, glaciers, and permafrost have resulted in significant downstream impacts in terms of the quantity, seasonality, and quality of water. This shrinkage has modified the water cycle and river discharge in cold regions and caused the rise of global mean sea level. Serving as a solid reservoir for many endorheic and exorheic basins, the mountain cryosphere is the regulator of major rivers and provides most of the water resources in arid regions in China and its neighboring countries. However, because of inadequate observation data and the lack of knowledge about many aspects of cryospheric hydrometeorology at regional scales in alpine regions, the significance of the impacts of cryospheric changes and the severity of their consequences remain unclear in China.
research objective: The scientific objective of the CHOICE is to obtain comprehensive observation data about environmental factors to determine the hydrological processes in a mountainous region and to evaluate the effects of climate, cryosphere, and land cover changes on mountainous hydrology and water resources in the lower arid regions. Four key science questions have been identified: The spatial and temporal distribution of alpine precipitation need to be determined. The effects of cryospheric changes on streamflow need to be determined. The effects of changes in the vegetation pattern in the vertical landscape zones on water balance and river runoff in the mountains must be assessed. A suitable distributed hydrological model including cryospheric hydrology is needed in mountainous areas.
challenges: Understanding such changes in these vulnerable regions has posed significant challenges because of their remoteness and sparse observations. Precipitation observations are still beset with significant biases and errors.
methods: Each AWS features the long-term monitoring of the following meteorological variables: air temperature, relative humidity, wind speed and direction, four-component radiation, soil heat flux, land surface temperature (LST), soil temperature, soil moisture, snow depth, and precipitation amount. We also conducted long-term standard meteorological field (SMF) manual observations for reference to those obtained at AWS. The total discharge has been monitored by a continuously stream-gauging station at the catchment outlet since 2009. From 2009 to 2012, we also manually used the float protocol and a stopwatch to estimate the nonfreezing period discharge in a meadow subcatchment and a moraineâ€“talus subcatchment. To apply hydrological models in the alpine catchment, we have obtained long-term continuous soil parameter data in the soil pit synchronously with those collected at AWS. An SI-111 infrared radiometer (Apogee Instr. Inc.) was used to measure the LST. During the early stage of the CHOICE, evapotranspiration was measured with two manual weighing microlysimeters, which were 40 cm in depth and 31.5 cm in diameter and were installed in the SMF at the Hulu-1 field on 1 July 2009 with an electronic scale of 2 g (0.026 mm) in precision. With the development of the CHOICE, five automatic microlysimeters (CHOICE-LYS40, T&D) were arranged in the same field as the AWS of the Hulu-1 to Hulu-5 field in August 2013. An EC150 system (Campbell Scientific Inc.) was installed on a lattice mast at 5.8 m at the Hulu-2 field in September 2011. Four cluster wells were installed in 2011 and 2014 for groundwater monitoring and sampling. On fixed-point scale, six SR50A Sonic Ranging Sensors (Campbell Scientific Inc.) measure snow depth synchronously with AWS. In this system, three thermistor cables were installed that crossed the riverbedâ€“water, waterâ€“ice, and iceâ€“air interfaces. We conduct the work of precipitation intercomparisons by referring to the Solid Precipitation Intercomparison Experiment of the WMO using pit gauges and a double reference intercomparison reference (DFIR) gauge. Precipitation measurements in the Hulu catchment were performed with six total rain-weighing sensors (TRwS204, MPS System Ltd) with a single alter shield and synchronized with AWS. Fourteen LST observation sites with similar elevations but different aspects and slopes were built around the Hulu-3 field. Two LST observation sites were built to analyze the influences of plants on LST. To study the runoff process of canopy precipitation to surface runoff in different landscapes, two runoff fields (shrubs and meadows) (15 by 3 m) were established at a shrub-encroached alpine meadow hillslope in September 2010. Four methods were used to measure soil water infiltration and hydraulic conductivity in the Hulu-1 field including a single-ring infiltrometer, a double-ring infiltrometer, a Hood infiltrometer (Hood IL-2700, Germany), and the ring cutter method. Groundwater samples used for isotope analysis were collected from 12 wells between 2014 and 2016, and stream water samples were collected from 12 sites that were approximately evenly distributed from upstream to downstream between 2011 and 2016. A Picarro GasScouter G4301 gas concentration analyzer with a re-entry control system and six respiration chambers installed on the permafrost zone of the Hulu catchment in August 2017. The observation period of canopy precipitation interception began in June 2010. A total of four sap flow sensors (CAF, ECOMATIK) were installed to estimate transpiration. Variations in the diversity of the soil microbial community under meadow, shrub, marshy meadow, and moraineâ€“talus were observed along an elevation gradient in the Hulu catchment in July 2013. An AWS was erected at the top of the glacier (4817 m asl) in September 2015; the site is not affected by the surrounding mountains. To obtain reliable turbulent data, EC system measurements were made adjacent to the AWS at a height of 4 m beginning in October 2017. To harvest the water contained in fog, five identical standard fog collectors were installed at Hulu-1 to Hulu-5 in July 2014. A warming simulation experiment was begun in September 2016. Two flight campaigns were performed in the Hulu catchment.
findings: In recent years, a series of studies have been published using the CHOICE sharing platform data, and a number of researchers have used the CHOICE data for studies of alpine meteorology, cryospheric hydrology, groundwater, soils, and isotopes. According to the six AWS of the CHOICE obtained throughout the Hulu catchment and peripheral precipitation data from five China Meteorological Administration stations (Zhangye, Minle, Sunan, Qilian, and Yeniugou), two or more yearly EMPs exist in the northern Qilian Mountains. A diminished accumulation zone will result in a reduction in the transport and expansion of the glaciers, and then the glaciers will have to retreat to limit themselves to reduce ablation. Based on 10-yr observations in the western cold regions of China, especially those obtained in the Upper Hei River basin (UHR), a new CBHM was created to evaluate the effects of cryospheric changes on stream flow from the UHR. In the past 50 yr, river runoff has generally shown an increasing trend as a result of increased rainfall, snowfall, and glacial runoff in the cold regions of western China.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'manual observations' in the context of meteorological data collection?
Definition.Answer: Manual observations refer to the systematic recording of meteorological data at specific times of the day, such as 8:00, 14:00, and 20:00, involving the measurement of various weather elements like temperature and ground temperature.

Definition.Question: What is the definition of an 'AWS' in meteorological studies?
Definition.Answer: An AWS, or Automatic Weather Station, is a setup used in meteorological studies for long-term monitoring of weather variables including air temperature, relative humidity, wind speed and direction, radiation, soil heat flux, and precipitation.

Comparison.Question: How do the methods for measuring evapotranspiration using manual weighing microlysimeters compare to automatic microlysimeters in terms of data collection efficiency and precision?
Comparison.Answer: Manual weighing microlysimeters were initially used to measure evapotranspiration with a precision of 2 g (0.026 mm) and required manual operation. Later, automatic microlysimeters were introduced, which improved data collection efficiency by automating the process and allowing for continuous measurement without the need for manual intervention. This shift likely increased precision and reduced human error in data collection.

Interpretation.Question: How can the observed variation in soil microbial community diversity along elevation gradients inform improvements in data collection methods for environmental monitoring?
Interpretation.Answer: The variation in soil microbial community diversity observed along elevation gradients suggests the need for diverse and location-specific data collection methods, such as including various landscape types like meadows, shrubs, and moraineâ€“talus, to accurately capture the ecological heterogeneity and its impact on hydrological processes.

Interpretation.Question: How does the implementation of multiple meteorological observation methods, such as automatic microlysimeters and EC systems, enhance the understanding of hydrological processes in mountainous regions?
Interpretation.Answer: The implementation of various meteorological observation methods, including automatic microlysimeters and EC systems, enhances understanding by providing comprehensive and precise data on evapotranspiration, land surface temperature, and other factors that are crucial for modeling hydrological processes and assessing the impacts of climate and environmental changes.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes challenges in obtaining accurate precipitation observations in remote alpine regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Understanding changes in vulnerable regions has posed significant challenges due to their remoteness and sparse observations, leading to significant biases and errors in precipitation observations.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is there a need for long-term continuous soil parameter data in alpine catchment studies?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: To apply hydrological models in alpine catchments effectively, it is necessary to obtain long-term continuous soil parameter data synchronously with those collected at automatic weather stations.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential impacts on data accuracy and completeness when using manual observation methods for meteorological data collection in mountainous regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Manual observation methods in mountainous regions can lead to challenges in data accuracy and completeness due to the remoteness and sparse distribution of observation points, which may result in significant biases and errors in precipitation observations.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to develop a comprehensive observation data collection strategy for cryospheric hydrology in mountainous regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The scientific objective is to obtain comprehensive observation data about environmental factors to determine the hydrological processes in a mountainous region and to evaluate the effects of climate, cryosphere, and land cover changes on mountainous hydrology and water resources in the lower arid regions.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the goals of implementing long-term standard meteorological field manual observations in alpine catchments?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Manual observations are conducted to provide reference data to those obtained at AWS, complementing automated data collection to ensure comprehensive monitoring of meteorological variables necessary for understanding hydrological processes and assessing the impacts of cryospheric changes.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it necessary to address challenges related to sparse observations and biases in precipitation data in remote cryospheric regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Understanding changes in these vulnerable regions has posed significant challenges because of their remoteness and sparse observations, and precipitation observations are still beset with significant biases and errors, which need to be addressed to accurately assess hydrological processes and the impacts of cryospheric changes.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are used to ensure the accuracy and reliability of precipitation measurements in the Hulu catchment?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Precipitation measurements in the Hulu catchment are performed using six total rain-weighing sensors with a single alter shield, synchronized with AWS. Precipitation intercomparisons are conducted by referring to the Solid Precipitation Intercomparison Experiment of the WMO using pit gauges and a double reference intercomparison reference gauge.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methods are implemented to measure soil water infiltration and hydraulic conductivity in alpine catchments?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To measure soil water infiltration and hydraulic conductivity, four methods are used, including a single-ring infiltrometer, a double-ring infiltrometer, a Hood infiltrometer, and the ring cutter method.

Enablement.Question: What technological tools or instruments are used to enable comprehensive data collection in mountainous cryospheric environments?
Enablement.Answer: Technological tools such as automatic weather stations (AWS), an SI-111 infrared radiometer, EC150 systems, SR50A Sonic Ranging Sensors, TRwS204 rain-weighing sensors, and Picarro GasScouter G4301 gas concentration analyzers enable comprehensive data collection in mountainous cryospheric environments.

Expectation.Question: Why might the expected outcomes of accurately determining the spatial and temporal distribution of alpine precipitation not be fully realized in this field?
Expectation.Answer: Understanding changes in vulnerable regions has posed significant challenges due to their remoteness and sparse observations. Precipitation observations are still beset with significant biases and errors, which may affect the accuracy of determining the spatial and temporal distribution of alpine precipitation.

Expectation.Question: What reasons might explain why the anticipated results of using hydrological models in alpine catchments could differ from expectations?
Expectation.Answer: Potential differences in anticipated results may arise due to inadequate observation data and the lack of knowledge about many aspects of cryospheric hydrometeorology at regional scales in alpine regions, which can affect the application and accuracy of hydrological models.

Expectation.Question: Why might the expectation of obtaining comprehensive observation data about environmental factors in a mountainous region not be fully met?
Expectation.Answer: The expectation might not be fully met due to the remoteness and sparse observations in these regions, which present significant challenges in collecting comprehensive data. Additionally, biases and errors in precipitation measurements further complicate data collection efforts.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using AWS and manual meteorological field observations for data collection in alpine regions?
Judgmental.Answer: The effectiveness of using AWS and manual meteorological field observations can be considered comprehensive, as they provide long-term monitoring of various meteorological variables like air temperature, relative humidity, wind speed and direction, and precipitation. These methods help overcome challenges posed by the remoteness and sparse observations in alpine regions and ensure a reliable reference for automated data.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential limitations of current precipitation measurement methods in mountainous regions, and how might they impact data reliability?
Judgmental.Answer: Current precipitation measurement methods in mountainous regions face significant biases and errors, which could impact data reliability. Challenges include the remote nature of these areas and the complexity of accurately capturing varied precipitation forms. This could lead to underestimates or overestimates in precipitation data, affecting hydrological models and water resource management.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about how the challenges of biased and erroneous precipitation observations are addressed in mountainous regions.
Assertion.Answer: Precipitation intercomparisons are conducted by referring to the Solid Precipitation Intercomparison Experiment of the WMO using pit gauges and a double reference intercomparison (DFIR) gauge. Additionally, rain-weighing sensors synchronized with AWS are used to improve accuracy.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how diverse environmental factors are integrated to study hydrological processes in alpine regions.
Assertion.Answer: The integration involves using AWS to monitor various meteorological variables, stream-gauging stations for discharge measurements, soil parameter data collection, and the use of different sensors and instruments to measure snow depth, soil moisture, and more. These data are then used to apply distributed hydrological models that include cryospheric hydrology.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges faced in measuring precipitation in alpine areas and suggest improvements to address these challenges.
Request/Directive.Answer: Precipitation measurements in alpine areas are challenged by significant biases and errors, often due to the remoteness and sparse distribution of observation sites. Improvements could include using a combination of pit gauges, double reference intercomparison reference (DFIR) gauges, and rain-weighing sensors with single alter shields, synchronized with AWS, to enhance accuracy and coverage.

Request/Directive.Question: Please investigate the potential for developing new datasets to study the impacts of cryospheric changes on streamflow in cold regions and recommend suitable data collection methods.
Request/Directive.Answer: To study the impacts of cryospheric changes, new datasets could focus on long-term observations of snow depth, soil temperature, and hydraulic conductivity using instruments like SR50A Sonic Ranging Sensors and infiltrometers. Combining these with groundwater and stream water samples for isotope analysis would provide comprehensive insights into streamflow dynamics.
